Welcome to the tenth iteration of this thread! Ask your simpler game questions here, and see them answered (usually!)

We use a particular format, so please be sure to number your questions and answers accordingly. Also, please attempt to search the forum before you ask; the answer may have been posted in a previous thread.

Format Example:

(Person with a question) Q1: If the ship moves, and we don't arrive at a planet, what happens to the planets we scanned?

(Person with an answer) A1: Those planets are lost forever, and you have to scan for new ones.

Q20: Is it true the target of being ill while expedition might be a Mush, and then human may work out that he isn't ill, which proves he's a Mush?
On october 5, 2014
[6826491]

A20: Yes. All they have to do is immediately heal that person after the expo, or have them get into a bed with a Shrink in the room. If there is no treatment result in either case, there's a good chance the player is Mush. Of course, sometimes the illness messages are wrong, and the person who is supposed to be ill isn't the one who got the illness. So, don't be too quick to kill someone just based on that. Most people will state what illness they got, in order to be properly treated.

[8433320]

On october 10, 2014
SummerMcLovin

A31: Regardless of how many spores you may have extracted/sourced from Cristalite zones, the MycoScan will always show "Pre-fungal level... zero" for a converted (or Alpha) Mush.
Ian's biography includes details about why this is the case, if you are interested in a lore perspective.

Using the MycoScan is a totally private action though, so you can make up any number you want. A human can also lie about this, but it isn't in their interest to do so - the Mush will already know how many spores they have, the humans may panic unnecessarily. Could even possibly be seen as playing against their team. They can of course keep it quiet that they know they are close to infection, only telling confirmed humans so the Mush don't rush to convert them before they remove any spores.
On october 10, 2014
MinerX

Q32: how long can someone be inactive with full hp before going highly inactive and starving to death after that? (if he ate right before he went inactive)
On october 10, 2014
SummerMcLovin

A32: Highly Inactive status is gained when you have not accessed the game for 48 hours. Technically you could avoid the Inactive status if Chao used Intimidating on you or Smallpox kept your AP below full.

Starvation starts 24 cycle after they reach 0 satisfaction. If they were on 0 when they ate, a Ration/steak would put them on 4, a fruit on 1, if they ate fruit before the Ration then add them up for a maximum of 6. Each cycle they would lose 1 HP, but they would also gain 1 HP each day change.
Assuming nobody heals them and no random damage, a Gold player who ate two fruit and a Ration in D1C2 would start to starve in D4C8 and reach 0 HP on D7C3 (unless starvation damage is removed after daily health is added, then it would be D7C1).

Maybe give or take a few cycles, I'm not quite sure but the mechanics are given here.

On october 10, 2014
[6826491]
CwovictorWhat if he ate a spaced potato just before going inactive? It gives 8 satisfaction, which is probably the highest satisfaction you can have at once.

A32: Actually, Organic Waste (only dropped by a player who is quarantined by the SDF) gives 16 Satisfaction. If they had a Satisfaction of 2 prior to consuming that, then 18 the highest possible Satisfaction one can have at once. It takes 24 cycles from the time your Satisfaction reaches zero, to BEGIN starving. Then you lose one HP per cycle due to starvation.

Assuming there are no injuries, illnesses, or environmental damage sources (or healing!) kicking in....

A Gold player could potentially survive a maximum of 58 cycles. (up to 18 Satisfaction, then 24 cycles to begin starving, and then 16 cycles from full health to starve to death.) However, death via another means is far more likely to occur before starvation.

A Bronze or Silver player could manage up to 56 cycles, under similar conditions. Again, they'd probably die long before reaching this number of cycles.

Coffee resets the hunger timer, despite being zero Satisfaction. So if they were well on their way to starvation, consuming any food or coffee will give them another 24 cycles to begin starving,

The most common item consumed in this case would be a ration, at +4 Satisfaction. So, (4 Satisfaction, then 24 cycles to begin starving, and 16 or 14 HP after that = 44 for Gold, 42 for Bronze/Silver.)

On october 11, 2014
[6826491]

A35: As far as Solid and Wrestler are concerned:

Solid adds +1 to the minimum and maximum damage for hand to hand attacks, so each hand to hand attack that hits will do 2-4 damage.

Wrestler is more effective, adding +2 to the minimum and maximum damage, making it 3-5 damage per hand to hand attack that hits. Additionally, if a human Stephen has both Solid and Wrestler, they STACK, making each hit 4-6 damage.

As for the messages, usually they're just flavor text, in regards to hand to hand attacks.

Q37: How does Logistic Expert work if this person is in the room with several other? I usually see that just one person in a few cycles a row gets additional AP from this. For example, I'm Frieda and earn some Logistics from Paola. Eleesha enters my room and as long as she was there, I couldn't get additional AP, it lasted 6 cycles.
On october 11, 2014
[6826491]

A37: A random person other than the Logistics Expert is chosen. If that player is already at full AP, then the AP bonus is wasted. This is why most ships don't want anyone other than Frieda (or whoever is the primary planet scanner) staying on the bridge with a Logistics Expert Paola...the Logistics bonus can be "stolen" by someone else, even if they're inactive.

As for Eleesha getting the LE bonus six times in a row, think of it like the flip of a coin, if there are two people who could get the bonus. Every time the coin is flipped, the chance is 50%, and that's just how it went for six cycles.

[8281990]
DinscrusaderQ40: What exactly is the legality of systematic Natamy Rifle testing (In which somebody goes around with the Natamy Rifle, shoots people even without due suspicion, and then checks to see how much damage was done). Would this fall under the same category of unfair testing as mandatory food tests for the whole crew? Or is it legal in the sense that medkit testing somebody when they come out of the shower is? At what point does it cross the line from legal human team protection tool to illegal police-ship tactic, if any?

I'd say the phrase "without undue suspicion" is the key line here. Anyone who showers (or enters the shower dorm) is possibly washing off the result of sporing, and thus is subject to a certain amount of suspicion. You can't test the people who have never been dirty. And if you check for stealth showers, you could get a false positive on a human who's had bad luck with item damage. Say a human gets hurt and dirty fixing an O2 tank, then comes to the dorm and gets hurt in the act of showering. A medkit test would be a false positive. A mush could also claim item damage to cover up a shower, or even have Splashproof. There's still an element of the unknown, truth to separate from lie.

Food tests and Natamy testing can't really be circumvented, which is why they're unfair to enforce. And the latter can do very nasty things to humans (your team), even if they don't take as much base damage.

[7950824]

A40 expanded: The SDF position on forcible mush or human testing is fairly strict; under most circumstances that testing is frowned upon. Note that I mentioned 'forcible'. A player who chooses to test themselves is not falling into that category (the method used to prove one's self human could potential be a separate problem, it is not alright to harm your ship by using essential resources up in the name of 'to show I am human' ).

If you wish to be completely safe in the use of forcible testing, you will use it only on individuals whom you already have enough evidence to outright kill because they clearly are mush. That means there will be extremely few cases where you will find any value in completely legal forcible mush testing - one example is a possible newbie who has done many things that appear good choices for a mush to do, but really appears to be a newbie who maybe made all these mistakes by accident; or could be an experienced player pretending to be a newbie with some skill, and using that to get a break and commit mayhem as a mush. If you want to save a possibly human newbie, you can offer them the ultimatum of proving themselves human (you'll probably have to explain how) or you can force a 'mush test' on them with the expectation of them dying from it, and stop when you realize a mush would have died but this player hasn't yet, seems you were wrong about them being mush.

It is specifically inappropriate to consider refusal to test as proof or even evidence that a player is mush. Both humans and mush are completely allowed to participate or refuse to participate in testing, and that refusal is proof of nothing.

It is also inappropriate to have a handful of mush suspects and simply go down the line 'testing' each of them until you find a mush. Testing should be reserved for the individual for whom a large amount of evidence has been gathered to show that they are probably mush, enough evidence that killing that player is completely justified; yet for whatever reason members of the ship decide to offer a chance to prove that there were mistakes or bad choices made, and the player actually is human despite their repeated, multiple mush-like but not-griefer choices. It is possible that more than one individual on a ship might be appropriate to demand a test of; but this would probably be an exceedingly rare occurrence.

If you observe forcible testing that appears to break these standards, regardless of if this is being done to you or others on your ship, I advise you to offer the information that the test is inappropriate (link to this post if you wish), and/or if you feel appropriate, report the offending player(s).

This also brings up the question of 'what is mush or human testing'?

For myself, and I speak as a player not as an official mod laying down the law, I consider the random use of torture or precognition to be foolish, but I myself would not sanction it as a mush test. I consider it an attempt to gather evidence. Torture especially is potentially abusable; repeated use especially upon the same subject without adequate evidence that it is a reasonable action could be reported as a form of griefing. Selective use of torture or precognition is quite reasonable.

Checking health with a medkit; again I consider this to be a form of gathering evidence and not a mush test.

'You can always use the natamy for testing' - this is extremely dangerous advice, both while on your ship in play, and if you are reported for griefing, random killing, or inappropriate mush testing.

The reason for this is that natamy almost always injures, and often causes multiple injuries; it is also very possible to kill a human in a single shot. If you already have enough evidence to kill the probable mush, then it is totally fine to 'test' them by shooting them once or twice with the natamy; a mush will die. A human probably will die too, but if you have enough evidence the player is mush then you may kill them and it doesn't matter how you kill them; killing them with the natamy is fine.

The problem comes when you have 'some' evidence, but not 'enough'. It is not alright to go test all or most of the people you or some of the people on your ship feel 'might' be mush; one of the clues that it's probably not time to kill yet is that you have a whole slew of suspects all looking about equally likely to be mush. This is to some extent subjective, but if you are reported for your actions, judges will be attempting to decide if there was enough evidence collected that the target was not a random pick or just one of a grab bag of suspects without significant evidence against them.

Telling a player, "Go eat two things or I will kill you because you're a mush": This is forcible human testing. Fine by the testing rules if you have significant evidence the player is a mush, but possibly playing against your team if that player is a mush and appears to have been tipped off to being caught by your actions (but if the multiple pieces of evidence you have were caused by mistakes or inexperience on the part of a human player, you may just save that player for your team; if this goes before the judges it is very much a judgment call). Otherwise, it's sanctionable as is any other forcible testing.

Leaving rotten food around to see who eats it and gets sick or not: Super dangerous, because mush can use fungal kitchen on it, but a form of evidence collection.

Killing a mush in a room with others present, then seeing who gets sick or not: Evidence collection, and unavoidable ("Excuse me, Mr Mush, would you please move one room so I can kill you without disturbing others?" .... inadvisable at best)

Counting AP and watching movement: Evidence collection.



I would urge all players to consider focusing more on collecting evidence then on trying to test, and to save forcible tests for those players who have so much evidence already gathered about them that you're ready to kill them without any further questions.

Remember, there are many, many forms of evidence, from 'rock solid' roomlog evidence someone is mush or human, to the subtle interplay of interaction and efficiency. Use it all, as much as you can think of, learn the evidence of mush and human play, and get out there and give each other the most awesome games possible. Be the best players you can be, be you mush or hunters!

Impet - in most situation the problem is not with collecting evidence, but to decide, if it's enough for a kill. For example botanist who just do watering once a day, say nothing and pass med with somebody. Now you can decide:
1) To tell him not to do it again. Maybe to watch him closely.
2) Kill right now
3) Test with natami

Let's see what outcomes will happen:
1a) He can be mush, maybe even mush with infector. One more "forgetting" from him or from his partner - and you got another mush (even if you take down them both just after that, before new mush do anything bad, you at least lost one more active human)
1b) It was just a mistake. You will watch one more suspect.
2a) You killed one mush
2b) You killed one human
3a) If he was mush, you killed hum with just 2 shoots for 2ap
3b) You shoot 2 times, he survived. Now you will need some ap to heal him, maybe he will need some ap for surgery. But you got confirmed human.
3c) He was human and died from natami. Chance of that is very low. Natami does 2-4 damage, max 8 to human. To kill full-hp human you need to do max damage and add 3 injuries with each shoot (you don't need to worry very much about -hp per cycle injuries as you can heal him after shooting). Headshots are also very rare things. In 50 ships I never did it myself and seen just once. Just don't double those chances with shooter.

Passive actions of the team like "collecting evidence" can look like more safe option, but you just give time and ways for mushes to do anything. Ha, if I see team just tell humans "not to go in med again" and do nothing, I will pass it myself as a mush and also say "oh, forgot" and make new mush. Now they have too many suspects to kill, and I have a new mush bro.
Yes, there is a risk to test like that, but it's not big, and killed mush is much bigger achivement, then 1 of 10 human dying from test is a problem.

Also remember - lots of mushes need only one time when you find their action suspicious. When they do second move - you will already have new mush, or humans killed. Easiest example - I got dirty with very weak reason, did 2 spores, waited, and went rampage. You could stopped me, with risking to test one player, now you lost 3-4.

DarkTheRaven

Q60 what is the benefit of hybridizing as oppose to just planting?
On october 20, 2014
Cwovictor

Q61: Can one get multiple injuries, like a broken hand and broken legs at the same time? What about illnesses?

Q61-B: If they do stack, what is the minimum amount of max HP one can have because of injuries and the suchlike?
On october 20, 2014
SummerMcLovin

A60: Hybridising a plant means that you don't need to wait two days for a plant to die of thirst for an empty HydroPot. The new young plant that you produce also gets a headstart in its cycles before maturity (more so if a Green Thumb hybridised it).
The downside is that you will have to be clean and the target plant has to be watered and disease-free.

If you have empty HydroPots to use instead, planting the fruit into them is usually better than hybridising.
On october 20, 2014
Kyubey

A60 Young plant will mature faster, if it was hybridized instead of planting. But in most situations you hybridize when you don't have free pots and plant if you have.
On october 20, 2014
SummerMcLovin

A61: You can have multiple injuries, either from multiple accidents/combat or from a single incident. I'm not sure if there is a maximum number in one go, but supposedly you can sometimes get three from a Natamy Rifle hit.

B: There are some illnesses (e.g. Food Poisoning) that also reduce your max HP, and more types of injury than Gold max HP of 16, so technically if you were healed every time you could have a maximum HP of 1 from a combination of the lot. You'll very likely die long before then, but a Casting ship might be able to test that.
On october 20, 2014
Kyubey

A61 Yes, you can. I have seen a mush with armor resist damage from 4 blaster shoots, get 1 point of damage from another shoot and 1 point of damage by punch. But he died after that (without cycle change). So his max hp was lowered by ~12 - some because of injury number, some because -max hp effects of some njuries he got. Also I have seen 2 injuries or illnesses on same person quite often.
On october 20, 2014
[6826491]

A61: To the already correct answers given so far, I'll add that the loss of HP from illnesses and injuries can stack. I once had two injuries, including a Critical Hemorrhage; I managed to cure the first injury, then I failed my second attempt at surgery, and gained the Sepsis illness. I was losing a total of 6 HP per cycle, and the Sepsis is what actually killed me.

Q66: I know this might not be good for here but i didn't really want to make a nother thread for it and i didn't find any threads relevant to what i'm gonna ask other than this but: Any advice on what skills i should aim to unlock first as a moderate-nearing advanced player? right now i just want to see what happend in the game and spend the exp i get along the way as i get it...
On october 22, 2014
Flash
Miner101XQ66: I know this might not be good for here but i didn't really want to make a nother thread for it and i didn't find any threads relevant to what i'm gonna ask other than this but: Any advice on what skills i should aim to unlock first as a moderate-nearing advanced player? right now i just want to see what happend in the game and spend the exp i get along the way as i get it...

A66: Aim to get at least Mush level 6 for Splash Proof and Transfer (last-mentioned being the most powerful) then level up your character of choice untill he/she has gotten the best skills. After that, aim to get Mush level 14 for Infector (because it's ridiculously good) and stop there. Any Mush skills above that level are either wasteful (Mass Mushification) or introduces boring gameplay (Pyromaniac). Then you level up other characters you really like (nothing's stopping you from playing characters you haven't fully leveled up too).

Notable human skills to get:

  • Raluca's Genius (for instant Pheromodem/Retrofungal Serum)
  • Andie's Polyvalent (help your ship in many ways)
  • Stephen's Apprentice (help where it's needed the most)
  • Janice's Diplomat (for glory whoreing... and helping your ship)
  • Gioele's Caffeine Junkie (to become an AP Legend)
  • Ian's Frugivore (to become an AP god).

Kyubey

A66
Characters who are good with 1 skill to play on Bronze and more skills will not change much:
Chun (MOH lvl 1)
Paola (Logistics lvl 2),
Derek (Shooter or Wrestler lvl 2)

Characters who are good with 2 skills to play on Silver and more skills will not change much:
Eleesha (Tracker+Observant lvl 3)
Frieda (Astro+IT lvl 4)
Hua (Pilot+something ship needs lvl 2-4)
KT (Tech lvl 4+something else)
Stephen (Apprentice on lvl 5. One more skill is useful for copying pilot+shooter for example but not needed too much)
Gioele (lvl 4 without Solid)

Characters who really shine with all 4 skills and Gold:
Andie (lvl 4, first 4 skills)
Ian (lvl 6, Frugivore+Green Thumb+Biologist+Botanist),
Janice (lvl 4, first 4 skills)
Jin Su (lvl 5 or lvl 6, he has more very good skills that you can take, just drop Cold Blooded)
Raluca (lvl 5, just drop DT)
Terrence (lvl 4, all skills are good)

ImpetA67 Yes. Once you are gold, you are gold until your gold days are gone, they are automatically used and cannot be shut off.

Followup Q67 a

Is there a way to buy the Welcome Pack without buying Gold?
On october 22, 2014
Flash

A67: to extend on Impets answer, the gold days are deducted every time the cycle changes for 8 to 1. You cannot stop using gold days once you have them.
On october 22, 2014
[7950824]

A67 follow up: Not that I am aware of. You can become Silver without buying gold, by using MT passes (which can be purchased or given to you, and I believe 1 or more MT games offer a way to competitively try to win them through play), but those passes do not activate the Welcome pack.

It is possible to give someone gold days, but that only gives them gold days for that duration; it doesn't activate the Welcome Pack and it does not cause them to become silver once those days are used. (So I have heard, I have not personally experimented with giving or receiving gold days).
On october 22, 2014
SummerMcLovin

Using MTPasses to get Gold will give you the Welcome Pack as far as I am aware.
Receiving Gold Days when you are Bronze definitely doesn't though, and you will revert to Bronze when they run out.

Technically if you aren't on a ship when you make your purchase/use MTPasses/receive your gifted days, then the Gold days will not activate immediately. As soon as you join a ship though, you will be Gold. If you die before they run out, they won't tick down until you join your next ship.

[8550239]

Sorry i'm slightly confused, i thought tracker affected shelves and interactable and once you touched then you were spored, are you saying that interacting with other players in a room will spore you too? what about boarding the icarus if theres a spore in the icarus shelf? also howmany spores can you get spored with via track at any one time?
On october 23, 2014
[8281990]

"Trapping the shelves" is more flavor text. Clicking on shelves to see what is on them will not trigger a trap. Dropping an item in a trapped room won't trigger the trap. But carrying out an action (such as picking up an item, using a terminal, or punching someone) will trigger the trap.
On october 23, 2014
[8550239]

Okay to continue with the example say mush frieda only has one health , the room shakes and she dies will the trapper spore still be on the shelf?
On october 23, 2014
[6826491]
NGJonOkay to continue with the example say mush frieda only has one health , the room shakes and she dies will the trapper spore still be on the shelf?

Yes. Chun is inherently immune to spores, so you could have her pick up and drop an item in that room, and it will safely "clear" the trap.
On october 23, 2014
[7950824]
NGJonOkay to continue with the example say mush frieda only has one health , the room shakes and she dies will the trapper spore still be on the shelf?

The only way that spore goes away is if 'someone' sets off the 'trap'. If that someone is already a mush, or is Chun, that spore is lost, wasted, has no effect and is gone. Anyone else gains +1 infection level, and the spore is gone. It is not possible to have more than 1 spore trapping 1 room at a time. But other rooms can also have 1 spore as a trap.


But not even fires will remove a spore. If the room has a spore, it has a spore until someone triggers the trap.

Q73 We went unto two missions one after the other, found lots of alien fruits but we come back and there's no fruit in the bay? glitch or did we do something wrong? Is it a common occurance?
On october 23, 2014
[7950824]

A73: Does your ship have 'food destruction' set to 'off'? If not, and if it was around day change, the fruit was automatically destroyed.

Check the roomlog. The moment you find the fruit, it is 'teleported' to Icarus bay. Someone can run in there during the expo (room has a max of 4 people in it at once, but while you're on expo, the room is empty cause you're on the planet) and eat, hide, or move it.

Shelves can be very full, with arrows to the sides to allow you to see the newest/oldest items. It's possible that you need to scroll if you haven't checked that.
On october 23, 2014
[6826491]

A73: You were on the expo close to the day change, weren't you? I'm guessing your Neron Admin didn't turn OFF the Food Destruction setting in the BIOS, and that's why your fruit was gone.

Other possible causes:

Someone came in during the expo and moved it. Fruits/artifacts found on an expo end up in the bay the moment you find them, so this is a common occurrence.

Or,

They came in and ate it. Less likely than the first two possibilities, and the first one is the most likely.

On october 23, 2014
[7950824]

A87 follow up: In the nexus there is a BIOS terminal. Once the ship fills, a NERON admin is selected, who has the power to change BIOS settings. Janice is the first to hold the title, if something happens to her there's a set order of new office holders.

One of the BIOS settings is 'food destruction', it defaults to 'on'. If that is the case, all coffee, fruit, and cooked rations that exist at day change cease to exist. If 'off', these items continue to exist, but age, steadily becoming more likely to cause a mild disease.

DarkTheRavenAnyone going to give an A90 a Paola's life kinda depends on it

Basically any consumable that changes appearance when cooked or frozen (like a standard ration becomes a cooked ration or vice versa) loses any spores it had on it at the time, a fruit doesn't change into a frozen fruit, it just gains the Frozen status so it doesn't lose the spores on it.

On october 26, 2014
[6826491]

A91: I was the mod who said that, and it was my experience, on a ship with just one Pilot (me, also the Commander for most of the voyage.) This was the ship in question. We had TM, and despite running repeatedly, we ended up with over 35 hunters in just one wave on D8. We continued moving after killing just the Aracks, and ended up with progressively more hunters with each new wave. First 38 arrived immediately, then 41 with the following wave. By the time the ship exploded, we only had a few people left alive, and 46 hunters outside...on D10. For the record, all of those were one wave each; you normally don't see waves of that size until past D15.

We had to keep running from hunters, since the Pasiphae was stolen early on, and the other pilots were either Mush or dead. What we found is that if you don't kill off the early hunters, the ones you left behind catch up to you in a few cycles, and you'll get abnormally large waves. It's well established that if you don't get any waves for a day or more, the next wave you get will be abnormally large. It will usually arrive as soon as you finish moving the ship. Case in point, I've seen a ship go over two and a half days without a new hunter wave, and then see 23 hunters arrive early on D4.

When you have smaller waves arrive, but you continue to run from them, you don't reduce their numbers...and they inevitably grow into a horde. It does take a few cycles for them to catch up to you, but their numbers will grow much quicker than if you were able to pick them off a few at a time.

SummerMcLovin
AcebMight have little higher chance to occur, but not sure at all.

Yes, a much higher chance of an accident from picking up Schroedinger than, say, the Wrench.
This can also occur when you cuddle him, not just picking him up, but putting him down and working on the Lenses are both safe. You can't get triple-spored from one "full interaction", but you could get two from picking up and cuddling.
Also noteworthy, Raluca cannot be scratched as it is her cat and is used to her. You'll have to rely on other methods to spore her, and if she claims a cat-scratch was the cause of some probably-shower-damage, she is lying.

Q 153 What are the time limits on how long someone has connected? What is "Recently", what is "A moment ago", etc.
On november 12, 2014
SummerMcLovin
DarkTheRavenA152 no matter what, Terrence does not need MP if someone else is in the room with him

Eh, not as far as I know. Terrence needs enough energy to leave the room (i.e. it won't work when he has the Broken Legs injury, or is totally out of both AP and MP). When someone else is in the room, it reduces Terrence's movement costs by 1 MP after he moves. Moving with a Heavy object will cost him 3 - 1 = 2 MP.

A153: I don't know exactly, but Online is "within the last 5-15 minutes" before going to Recently. A moment ago seems to be around three hours (i.e. a normal cycle) since the last action. A long time ago is either six, nine or twelve hours since last action.

Flash
Addem-UpQ 153 What are the time limits on how long someone has connected? What is "Recently", what is "A moment ago", etc.

Generally, from what I've seen, actions that add to the room logs (publicly visible or otherwise) and posting in private chats will refresh the status. Note: does not update if posting in general- or Mush chat.

Online: 0-5 min after the action
Recently: 5 min - 3 hours
Moment ago: 3 - 9 hours (could be 3 - 6 hours, I don't remember)
A long time ago: Any time beyond the above.

Items like bananas or coffee don't change but instead get the frozen status and keep any spores they had.

leverdatre

A 158: A man in my game tell me that GPU make the ship fall out even faster.
Is it right or bullshit?
On november 13, 2014
[6826491]

A158: It's not exactly what happens, but what you've been told is somewhat right. What GPU does is not "prevent events from happening", as it would seem to in the description...but it seems to instead delay when they occur. This is why I believe it to be bugged. If you have it trigger a few times in a row, the bad events get delayed and stockpiled for the next cycle, in which they may potentially be delayed again. The next time GPU fails to stop any bed events, you'll have more of them happening at once in that cycle.

Conclusion: If you have GPU against any projects that can counter or remove the damage of events, like Armored Corridors, Extra Drone, or Automatic Sprinklers, then do not choose GPU. It is better to have a Robotics Expert to upgrade your drones, than it is to rely on GPU, since you'll have the same number of fires/broken equipment in the long term. The difference with having GPU is that when these events hit you, you will have more of them hit you at once!

The same can be said of Trail Minimizer and hunters. The hunters you think you left behind will just catch up to you in a few cycles, and if you move the ship a lot without killing them...you can end up with 30-40 hunters every new wave, before the end of Day 8 or Day 9. I've experienced that firsthand, and TM doesn't actually help matters.

A158: It's not exactly what happens, but what you've been told is somewhat right. What GPU does is not "prevent events from happening", as it would seem to in the description...but it seems to instead delay when they occur. This is why I believe it to be bugged. If you have it trigger a few times in a row, the bad events get delayed and stockpiled for the next cycle, in which they may potentially be delayed again. The next time GPU fails to stop any bed events, you'll have more of them happening at once in that cycle.

Conclusion: If you have GPU against any projects that can counter or remove the damage of events, like Armored Corridors, Extra Drone, or Automatic Sprinklers, then do not choose GPU. It is better to have a Robotics Expert to upgrade your drones, than it is to rely on GPU, since you'll have the same number of fires/broken equipment in the long term. The difference with having GPU is that when these events hit you, you will have more of them hit you at once!

I've experienced that firsthand, and TM doesn't actually help matters.

I honestly have no reason to believe that is true. Until there is plenty of evidence that shows GPU hurts you more in the long run, I'm going to continue to advocate GPU above many projects. I also have no reason to believe that Trail Minimizer hurts in the long run. I do believe moving the ship increases the chance of generating a new wave of hunters, but I don't have any reason to believe old hunters eventually catch up. As far as I can tell, if no old hunters show up when you arrive at your new destination, they will never show up again.

Q 163 -- Let's say that Janice is idle and Eleesha is NERON admin. Then Janice wakes up. Does Janice become NERON admin as soon as she wakes up or only upon cycle change?
On november 14, 2014
[6826491]

A163: At the following cycle change. If Janice takes no actions during the following cycle (in which she regains the title,) then Eleesha will get the title back at the beginning of the next cycle.

So, in C1, Janice logs in and becomes active again.
C2, she gets the title, unless she dies during C1.
If she takes no actions in C2, she'll be marked inactive again at the end of the C2.
In C3, Janice loses the title, and Eleesha gets it back.
On november 14, 2014
[8216957]

hippogryph

Q166 : What actions will reset my "Dismantle" progress? (sleeping in particular)
On november 14, 2014
[6826491]

A166: Any expenditure of AP (or free points from a skill) on a different action will reset your progress. That includes AP-MP conversion. If you were to say, start dismantling a shower, fail a few times, and immediately sleep, your progress will remain the same.

You could also conceivably attempt to dismantle the Alpha Dorm shower, fail it, use only MP (without any AP-MP conversion involved) to head to Bravo Dorm, and sleep there. If you don't attempt any other actions before you return to AD and continue dismantling, you will keep your progress.

Note that if you have a condition that makes ordinarily free actions (like lying down) cost additional AP, that will probably reset your progress; but I haven't personally confirmed it.

Q172: When using trapper to place a spore, can the trapping mush destroy the spore themselves by accessing the trapped item?
e.g. Ian traps a hydropot. Ian waters the hydropot immediately. Does Ian's watering destroy his own previously placed spore?
On november 18, 2014
DarkTheRaven

A172 Yes, most actions within a room will set the trap off, if a mush sets it off the spore is lost
On november 18, 2014
1412

A172a:
Chun doing something will also destroy the trap, if it weren't obvious.
On november 18, 2014
SummerMcLovin

A172: You don't trap items, you trap that room and everything in it. If the Lab were trapped then interacting with the plants, picking up items, accessing the Research Terminal or even using the MycoScan (that'd be a nice conversion) will activate the trap. Things like reinstalling a Nimble-Fingers-removed Camera or Green Jellying something in that room will also activate them, wasting the spore, so do the latter before you trapper (and just avoid using Nimble Fingers at all, it isn't very good).
Putting items down (including hiding them), walking through the room, and as far as I know interacting with people will not leave the trap intact.

[6826491]

Yeah, you're in for a "fun" time, I'm sure. At least you're not guaranteed to lose.


A202: As a Mush, your morale value is locked, and it doesn't change due to player deaths, day changes, panic attack events, from eating consumables, being comforted by a Shrink, or any other means. (Note that when you're Comforted, or in bed with a Shrink in the room, you'll still get the morale gained message, even though it can't affect you.) This is why it's important to keep track of how much morale you should have, because if you should be dangerously low, and you're not seeking aid to remedy that situation, you might seem suspicious.

As a result of Mush being unable to increase their morale, if you happen to Transfer into a player who also happens to be at zero morale, you'll put an end to it all at the end of the cycle.

On december 6, 2014
[7950824]

Q215

Actually, you have a fuzzy grasp of the start of the plan... so starting you over. Duplicated numbers can happen concurrently.

1 find 1 starmap fragment
2 take it to the lab
3 research calculator
3 find 2+ additional starmap fragments
4 take at least 3 starmap fragments to the nexus and place on the shelf (note fragments are not flammable, have never been reported being destroyed or damaged at least)
5 be clean and have a lot of AP, click on the new clickable in the nexus and spend AP like water. Note that resets are not possible, the solution is more like repairing an object or doing comms work. Once the way has been opened, it stays open and Eden can be gone to in the same manner and cost as the jump back to Sol would be done, just a different button for the command terminal.

Rain
Gardevoirq218 - Why do people shout "For Delzoup, Aaeni!" or something when they go berserk?

Delzoup is the goddess of mush slaying. When you lay the corpse of a mush upon the altar of Delzoup, She is pleased and will smile upon you, blessing your future endeavors. So it is written, and so Her disciples have found it to be.

You may see corrupted ones dedicating their sacrifices to Aaeni or even Sstrickl, or even, believe it or not, using Delzoup's name in vain. These heathens walk a dark, potentially mushy path. However, Delzoup, in Her wisdom, is merciful, and will forgive them if they should truly repent and dedicate themselves to Her. Therefore, all reasonable attempts to bring these corrupted ones to the light should be made before more drastic measures.

TeufelsAdvokat
MandyQ219 : Who is the best character suited for Beginners? Thanks Addem-UpA219: Depends. Do you want a simple character to play, or one that has no suspicion of being Mush, or one that's easy to roleplay?

I wouldn't recommend to choose a character, who's easy to roleplay. First comes gameplay. Decent roleplay isn't required, it isn't even necessary at all. Game basics, meaning dos and don'ts are crucial however. Same goes for characters, that are easy to play as mush. How does one pretend to be human, if he doesn't know much about the game? Wouldn't bother with it.

Important for a good (first) character choice are in my opinion activity and difficulty of the human job. For example an Ian, who has to log in once a day, water and treat plants and do some research is easier to play than Jin Su or Eleesha, who have to know about so many aspects, if they want to fulfill their job decent.

There are some Mushpedia pages, that may give you a quick overview about the characters (click) or generalist or special tasks and titles (click).

SummerMcLovin

A225: You can have your Spacesuit stolen, but the expedition will continue as normal. Should you need to relaunch, you will need to pick up another Spacesuit or you will be left in the Icarus.

A226: As far as I know, the plant you graft onto doesn't have an effect on the maturity of the new alien (or Banana, if for some reason you go back) plant. As long as it is healthy and watered, and the grafter is clean, the new plant will still have a small head start towards maturity. Green Thumb and the Nano-ladybugs Gold Project will have an effect though: the former giving an extra head start; I think the latter would change it to only requiring six cycles to mature (never used it myself) or it may give an extra head start.

On december 8, 2014
DarkTheRaven
ZmaxterIs there a certain number of levels we can attain before unlocking new slots, or do levels merely unlock abilities, and we need gold mode to unlock the remaining three slots?

To elaborate more specifically on the previous answer, when you start playing the game you play as a bronze member this gives you 1 skill slot a walkie talkie, and a tracker

you can buy the equivalent of membership known as gold days when in gold mode you can have up to 4 skills depending on if you've unlocked 4 skills for a given character even if you have gold mode, if your character is only level 1 you will only have access to 1 skill until you level it up this also lets you join up to 4 castings at a single time, and unlocks the iTrackie (combination of a tracker and a walkie talkie) permanently

after your gold days run out you will play in silver mode this allows you to have 2 skills, the iTrackie, unfortunately if you joined 4 castings as a gold member you have to quit 3 before you can launch with any of them
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
So for a summary:

Bronze mode:
-the free-to-play mode of Mush, unlocked by making an account
-1 skill slot
-walkie talkie and tracker
-Earn 1 per cycle

Gold mode:
-The 'membership' of Mush, available for purchase (please note the payment is in Euros) alternatively you may use MTPasses to buy gold days
-Allows up to 4 skills providing the character you're playing as has 4 skill unlocked
-earn 2 per cycle rather than 1
-iTrackie (combination of tracker and walkie talkie) unlocked permanently
-If it is your first time purchasing gold days you will receive 80
-While gold mode is active you will have 2 more and 2 more

Silver mode:
-Unlocked by paying for gold mode at least once, if you buy gold days 1 time you will never revert back to bronze mode, you will play as silver once the gold days run out
-2 skill slots, again providing the character you are currently playing as has 2 skills
-iTrackie available
- Earn 1 per cycle

for a full guide see: Mushpedia, Game modes

[6826491]

A232: Sometimes we have to nuke threads. It happens for various reasons, but don't expect us to give the details as to why. Please don't speculate about it when it happens, either. It's not helping, and it tends to get spammy.

A233: It only sees the very last action they took. As a result, it can't possibly "see" further back than that, unlike Confident or Torturer. Pave

This for the most part is highly not recommended move: It can backfire really badly (at least as a Polyvalent)!
Earlier example of +40-cycles-to-maturity-requiring young banana plant was at 20-cycles left. I grafted/ hybridized it into much better general-food-poisoning-healing one: The new required cycle-required for this plant was 47!
So apparently grafting a young plant actually resets the maturity instead of "re-rolling" a new one like with already mature-plants...

There is no re-rolling of maturity, ever to my understanding. Grafting a fruit to a plant, mature or young, 'starts over' with the new plant's stats, one of which is 'time to maturity'.

That can range from 1-48 cycles.

It doesn't matter if you graft to a young or mature plant, or plant it outright in an empty pot, if you are working with a fruit type that needs 47 cycles to mature, that's what it needs. Now, those cycles can be affected by stuff like hydroponics, but that is true for all cycles of immaturity, short or long.

[7950824]

So you're saying you had a banana plant which required 47 cycles to reach maturity?

That would be unique in my experience of these games.

Bananas (and jumpkins) are defined. As far as I know, and as far as I've seen on ship after ship, all bananas require 36 cycles to mature. 4.5 days, without other measures.

All other fruit types are randomized between ships, needing 1-48 cycles to mature.

You created a new aspergunk plant from a Filandra. Filandra are random each ship - For your ship you have discovered they need 47 cycles to mature.

This will be true if you plant into an empty pot, if you graft onto a mature plant, or if you graft onto a young plant as you have - long as you graft right, you get a plant that needs 47 cycles. Has nothing to do with the young banana you used to have - and that banana did not, unless something very weird was going on, need more than 36 cycles to mature.

Q244a What are the "Mush" actions that does not require a spore?
Q244b How to play as a mush without getting dirty?
On december 12, 2014
[1820396]

A244a: It's easier to do a list of things that DO need a spore to work:
infecting anyone (directly or through doing the thing, or even petting the Schrödinger)
trapping a shelf with Trapper skill
trapping a consumable item with Fungal kitchen skill
transfering with Transfer (not really need for transfer itself, but the victim has to be infected at least once)
eating the spore with Phagocyte skill

Everything else can be done without any use of spores.
(unless I forget some not much seen and used high level skill)
On december 12, 2014
sperbi

A244b: Your question is ambiguous. There are 2 possibilities:
a) try to hide that you got dirty:
Showering doesn't leave a log, so if you shower without soap, noone will notice that you showered. So you can do for example an extraction of spores in a room without people/cameras and then do a sneaky shower. Though it will cost you 2 ap without soap and you have to enter the dorm with the shower.Therefore it could also make sense to just search for good excuses why you got dirty to cover your mushy activities.

b) no extraction of spores at all:
Hm, that means you plan to hurt the humans by not converting people and stay without suspicion?
a possibility would be to take traitor skill (especially useful of you are also survivalist and astrophysicist to find dangerous planets) and hope for bad events on expo - traitor skill is increasing chances for bad events (like people get lost and found MIA, fight events, ...). Since it needs luck it is probably not very reliable. Then there is the mushy skill demoralize. With that skill you could demoralize people and make them die because of depression (problem is often to not know exact amount of morale of the person so you often have to use much aps to make sure that the person is really dieing or you are busted). That action is covert and you shoudl use it before day change. Still it could make yourself suspicious unless there were hints that the person had already a very low morale.
Also there is the skill slimetrap. You could make people suspicious by making them dirty. But it will mostly only work for inactive people. some active people could destroy your effort just by doing a mush test. And killing inactive people as mush doesn't make much sense.
Using of green jelly to sabotage equipment sneakily is possible, if used rarely. Otherwise it woudl make yourself suspicious after some time. All in all the most effective mush actions involve the production of spores unless you are using tactics which doesn't need mush skills (like pilgred rush, fuel rush).

When would a harmful return to SOL be sanctionable? Always. Harmful returns are, by definition, a violation of the rules. There are plenty of non-harmful returns to Sol, those are not sanctionable.... because they are not harmful returns.

Roleplay does not justify breaking the rules. No defense of rulebreaking behavior can be successfully made by saying 'it was roleplay', or 'it makes sense because of roleplay'. Roleplay is permitted, and welcome on the ships, as is non roleplay. All play is welcome on the ships, so long as it does not break the rules. Roleplay to your heart's content - but don't break the rules, with or without rp.

You did not ask 'What is the difference between a harmful return to Sol and a non-harmful return to Sol', which is a great thing to make sure you understand to ensure that you play within the rules regarding returns to Sol.

Triplewitching

You're welcome to ask about what is unclear to you.

Perhaps this will appear to lack 'hemming and hawing' for you:

A harmful return to Sol is one made by one or more humans while the ship is in a condition where it appears very likely that the ship and most of the crew will safely continue into the future, made when a large majority of the players have not stated they prefer to return to Sol, which one or more players report as a harmful return to Sol, and a panel of judges and/or mods review and vote to agree it was indeed a harmful return to Sol.

A return to Sol with much discussion, and eventual agreement by actives, despite the ship able to continue: Legal.

A return to Sol when the hull is low, many hunters are present, and the pilots have already spent most of their AP or are known not to be able to log in until it would probably be too late: Legal.

A return to Sol when the ship could definitely survive longer and believes itself to be mush free, with 11 highly active players wish to return to Sol and 3 highly active players who wish to continue: Highly questionable, and probably would be voted as a hostile return if reported. Talk, when that circumstance happens. Negotiate, or just keep playing your best and check again as conditions change.

[7950824]

However, there are situations where it is completely appropriate for one player to make the decision to return to Sol, without any discussion with anyone. In fact, it can be vital for the human wincon for any player to be able, potentially at least, to initiate the return to Sol without any votes in agreement. Here's an example:

Things are going great, it's day 13, two starmaps found, a safe-seeming planet that may give the third starmap, large human crew having a lot of fun in the game.

Something happens to block access to the game for most of the players. A couple are able to log in, none of them pilots. A huge wave of hunters appears. They can move the ship, but not safely do the expo alone; they decide to wait it out. Healing, plant care, necessary repairs are keeping them busy; Shield goes down, hull gets low, no other players have connected in the last few cycles and it's pretty clear that the ship will be dead in a cycle or two. One of them hacks and returns to Sol.

Someone on the ship reports it as a possible hostile return to Sol.

Reviewing that record, I would vote 'cleared'. But if programming required a vote with a certain number of 'recently active' players to vote yes or no and/or required a number of cycles to pass before the vote closed - that ship and others like it would be forced to die in space. The owners of this game have chosen to allow freedom, and a justice system to handle rulebreakers. It's also fine to report suspected rulebreakers; we have a 'cleared' option. It can be hard to know what is going on as a player, so reasonable reports to check for suspected wrongdoing are acceptable. Utterly random 'hey, did so and so do something wrong this ship?' should be avoided.
